type1_workflows.name: Propagating supported fields through layered frameworks
type1_workflows.description: A general strategy to wire an already-supported field from the output/generator layer back through upstream view/controller layers so it appears in generated artifacts.
steps: Step 1: Verify the output or generator layer already supports the target field by reviewing its API and output format
Step 2: Trace the data flow upstream to identify where items are constructed and passed to the generator
Step 3: Inspect the view/controller layer for dynamic attribute accessors or mapping patterns for item fields
Step 4: Implement the pass-through by adding the missing field to the existing mapping using established dynamic access patterns
Step 5: Add or update tests to assert the field appears in the generated output (e.g., RSS element) and follows expected behavior
Step 6: Validate with a minimal reproducer and run the relevant test subset to ensure no regressions

type1_workflows.name: Enhancing Django’s syndication Feed with new item_* attributes
type1_workflows.description: A Django-specific workflow to add a new item_* attribute to the syndication framework and ensure it is passed to the feed generator.
steps: Step 1: Review django/utils/feedgenerator.py to identify supported item fields and their parameter names
Step 2: Inspect django/contrib/syndication/views.py to see how item_* methods on Feed are mapped to add_item() parameters
Step 3: Add a new item_* method on Feed subclasses and propagate it by passing the corresponding parameter to feed.add_item() via the dynamic attribute accessor
Step 4: Mirror existing tests in tests/syndication_tests to assert the output (e.g., RSS <comments> element) includes the new field
Step 5: Run the syndication_tests subset with Django’s test runner and iterate until the new behavior is verified
Step 6: Update documentation for the Feed API if the new item_* attribute is public and intended for feed authors

type2_workflows.name: Navigating Django’s syndication and feedgenerator code to wire a missing field
type2_workflows.description: Concrete steps to locate relevant files, confirm generator support, and add pass-through logic in the syndication views.

steps.reasoning: Need to find the modules that implement syndication and feed generation to locate integration points.
Confirm the syndication app layout and locate views where feed items are constructed.
Inspect the syndication views to find where add_item() is called and how dynamic attributes are retrieved.
Verify the feed generator supports the target field and determine the exact parameter name to pass.
Confirm the presence of the target field (e.g., comments) in the feed generator.
Identify the current add_item() call in views to see which fields are already passed through.
Implement the pass-through by adding the missing parameter mapping in the add_item() call following existing patterns.
steps.action: Open /workspace/django/django/contrib/syndication/views.py in your editor and add within feed.add_item(...): comments=self._get_dynamic_attr('item_comments', item)

steps.reasoning: Ensure coding style and patterns match adjacent parameters for consistency.
steps.action: Review nearby parameters (e.g., categories=self._get_dynamic_attr('item_categories', item)) in views.py and mirror the same structure

type2_workflows.name: Running Django syndication tests and a minimal reproducer
type2_workflows.description: Concrete steps to validate behavior via the Django test runner and an ad-hoc script to reproduce and inspect field propagation.

steps.reasoning: Examine existing syndication tests to learn how item_* fields are asserted and ensure consistent coverage.
Check whether the target field (e.g., comments) is already covered; if not, plan new tests.
Install Django in editable mode so the test suite runs against local code changes.
Run the syndication test subset using Django’s dedicated test runner to quickly validate changes.
Iterate faster on a focused test to see RSS output and confirm the new field appears.
Create a minimal reproducer script to validate end-to-end field propagation without relying on the full test harness.
steps.action: Create /workspace/test_item_comments.py that defines a Feed subclass with item_comments() returning a URL, then run: cd /workspace/django && python /workspace/test_item_comments.py

steps.reasoning: If environment constraints interfere with the reproducer, use an inline script to bootstrap Django and exercise the Feed class.
steps.action: cd /workspace/django/tests && python -c "import django; django.setup(); from django.contrib.syndication import views; class F(views.Feed): pass; print('Django setup OK')"
